Note: 1. ISO refers to Country ISO Code if it is a national or subnational bank. "MB" is used to refer to multinational bank. According to the UN standard, see https://unece.org/trade/cefact/unlocode-code-list-country-and-territory https://unstats.un.org/unsd/tradekb/Knowledgebase/Country-Code.

Definition: Name of Bank in English Language
Note: Refer to the name as "official" as possible; use English official names if available; keep the name in original non-English language if it is widely used

Definition: Name of the Deveopnment Bank in original language
Note: Refer to official names from official website.

Definition: Acronym of the name of the Developnment Bank
Note: Refer to annual reports, official websites for the acronym; if not available from official sources, use the initial letter of each word in the English name.

Definition: The calendar year when the deveopnment bank articles of agreements were officially approved or signed (instead of the year when the Bank started its operation); use the establishment year of the parent institution if there is restructuring (even though the name or business models may be changed after restructuring)
Note:
1. Search the Articles of Agreement and find the year when the Articles of Agreement were signed;
2. Search the history in the official website to find the "earliest" year of the establishment, i.e., if a Developnment Bank is founded at certain year X but restructured in year Y, we record X as the establishment year.

Definition: The official mandate stands for the mission to fulfill a particular public policy that a Developnment Bank is mandated to carry out.
Note: We first classify the official mandates into flexible or not. Flexible (FLEX) means that official mandates are not confined to a specific mission. If they are not flexible, we further classify them by specific sectors or clients, including rural and agricultural development (AGRI), mainly promoting exports, foreign trade, but also includes other activities such as overseas investment (EXIM), social housing (HOUS), infrastructure (INFRA), international financing of private sector development (INTL), local government (LOCAL), and micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSME).

Definition: Name of the country/economy that owns the Developnment Bank
Note: If it is owned by more than two countries/economies, use "Multi".

Definition: According to their ownership structure, Developnment Banks are classified into three categories: multinational, national, and subnational. Multinational, initiated and owned by entities from more than two countries; national, created and owned by a central government (or national public entities), or private sectors in rare cases; and subnational, established and owned by a local government entity or jointly by several local governments.
Note: If the bankl is set up by two central governments, we classify it as national, since under these circumstances it is easy to identify which country is the majority shareholder. Even if the two countries’ shares are 50/50, we can use other indicators such as the headquarters, main customers, and operators to determine which country of the two is the “main character”.

Definition: Dummy variable, which denotes whether the banks main activities are restricted within specific subnational areas. If it is restricted, then it is "subnational"; If not, then "national".
Note: For any single Developnment Bank, international and regional are marked as mutually exclusive, as an institution that can operate internationally can, by definition, also operate in its own geographical region. This is also applied to subnational versus national.

Definition: We use total assets as a criterion to classify the deveopnment bank into five size categories: mega (more than $500 billion), large (between $100 billion and $500 billion [included]), medium (between $20 billion and $100 billion [included]), small (from $500 million to $20 billion [included]), and micro (less than and equal to $500 million).
Note: The classification is based on total assets in the year of 2023; if not available, the data on total assets in previous years (2016-2022) is used.

Definition: Total assets of the bank in million USD
Note:
1. Use consolidated financial statements if available; otherwise, use the unconsolidated ones.
2. Database before Q4 2023 (included):
i. If the fiscal year ends on or before June 30, 20XX, the data should be recorded as for 20XX-1; conversely, if the fiscal year ends on or after July 1, 20XX, the data should be recorded as for 20XX.
ii. If the presentation currency is not U.S. dollars, the data is converted to U.S. dollars using the exchange rate as of December 31 of the year available at https://xe.com/.
Database after Q1 2024 (included): 
i. If the fiscal year ends on or before June 29, 20XX, the data should be recorded for the year 20XX-1; if the fiscal year ends on or after June 30, 20XX, the data should be recorded for the year 20XX.
ii. If the presentation currency is not USD, the data is converted to USD using the exchange rate for fiscal year-end date available at https://xe.com/.

Variable Name:
Total Equity/Total Liabilities/Net Income/Profit before Tax/Net Interest Income
(Million USD)
Definition: Total Equity/Total Liabilities of the bank in million USD
Note:
1. Use consolidated financial statements if available; otherwise, use the unconsolidated ones.
2. If the fiscal year ends on or before June 29, 20XX, the data should be recorded for the year 20XX-1; if the fiscal year ends on or after June 30, 20XX, the data should be recorded for the year 20XX.
3. If the presentation currency is not USD, the data is converted to USD using the exchange rate for fiscal year-end date available at https://xe.com/.

Definition: The official website of the Deveopnment Bank
Note: Occasionally the official website of few Banks may not be publicly available.

Definition: The link to products lines/ Programs of the banks/ financial statements
Note: The product lines vary from Bank to bank
